prompt:
List the things you only want to do if they can be done perfectly. 
 What is one thing on your list you are willing to put time and effort into, even if you never reach perfection?
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 76-77.
bonus_text: The fact is, we often have to try something multiple times to get anywhere close to doing it well. Perseverance is more valuable than talent. Remember that. Some estimate that it takes ten thousand hours of practice to master something, and while enherent talent does make it easier, no one is talented in every area of life. What is one thing you are willing to put time and effort into, even if you never reach perfection?

prompt: What is a boundary you need to draw in your life?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 33

prompt:
How would your friends describe you? 
 How do you feel about those descriptions
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 3

prompt:
What is a made-up rule about your life that you are applying to yourself? 
 How has this held you back and how might you change it?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 15

prompt: List the assets in your life that you would benefit from investing more time into, whether it be people, physical resources, activities, or skills.
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 58-59.
bonus_text: Pick the easiest thing on your list you can invest in this week. Put an asterisk next to it. Once you pursue it, write down what you feel you gained from redirecting attention to something you already have.

prompt:
What are 3-5 memories that would help someone understand who you are as a person? 
 What emotions do you associate with each memory?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 70

prompt:
When you were a child, how did you imagine your adult life? 
 How does that compare to the way it is now?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 180

prompt: List the things you visualize having, doing, and being in your dream life
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 28-29.
bonus_text: Next to each of the things that you don't have in your life currently, write 'not yet.' Because that is the truth. You have time. You may not have the things you want and need right now, but in life, you have the chance to pursue that which you need and want - if not now, soon - with bravery. You are NEVER a failure if you allow yourself to try again.

prompt: List the things you once dreamt of having in your life that you DO have now
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 30-31.
bonus_text: How did each of these things come into being? Put an asterisk next to things that required bravery to attain

prompt: Write about a favorite memory of being recognized for something you did.
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 27

prompt: What is a reminder that you would like to tell yourself next time you are in a downward spiral?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 2

prompt:
Think about a typical day for you. 
Every day I face the challenge of:____ 
And every day I show I am brave by: _____
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 118-119.
bonus_text: Look back on this list when you're facing a bigger challenge to remind yourself of all the ways you problem-solve, push through, and rise to the occasion on a day-to-day basis. You are so capable.

prompt: Write about a mistake that taught you something about yourself
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 28

prompt: List the people who make you feel at ease and the spaces where you can relax
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 128-129.
bonus_text: We can't expect ourselves to be warriors of bravery every day. You are a multifaceted person who deserves a little rest and relaxation amidst your pursuits. And spending time with people who give us space to express ourselves is a good source of emotional rest. Take some time to rest your heart today, whether it is alone or with the people you feel comfortable with.

prompt: How do you take praise? How do you take criticism?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 157

prompt: List the criticisms you've received in the past that have helped you to become a better you
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 98-99.
bonus_text: Allowing criticism to exist in your life is one of the greatest markers of bravery. You can and will bounce back fro critique IF you decide to give yourself the chance to practice receiving it (especially when it hurts). The next time you hear criticism from someone, follow these steps: 1. Respond with 'Thanks for the feedback.' 2. Take time to process your feelings, either alone or with someone else. 3. Decide what percentage of their feedback you want to take, and use it to your advantage. Then let go of whatever feels like it isn't needed for your personal growth.

prompt: List the times you have had to disappoint someone to do what you believed was right for you?
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 78-79.
bonus_text: One of the bravest acts is to follow your gut and do what you believe is right for you, even when someone you love may disagree. Who is one person whom you feel you have disappointed in the past, but who is still in your life and shows you they love you in their own unique ways?

prompt: What is something that you recently blamed yourself for? Now that some time has passed, how do you think about it differently
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 348

prompt: Write about a time you felt that you deserved an apology and never received one. What would you have liked that person to say?
List the ways you have forgiven yourself
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 138-139.
bonus_text: Is it easier for you to forgive others or forgive yourself? A huge part of building resilience in yourself is to allow present you to forgive past you. You get to grow and change for the better. Equally, those around you deserve the chance to try again, do better, and be better. If you have an easier time forgiving others, think of how you love them next time you are criticizing yourself, and apply that love to you. You are your greatest friend and family!

prompt: Write about something for which you would like to forgive yourself
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 460
bonus_text: Remember what you learned last week - A huge part of building resilience in yourself is to allow present you to forgive past you.

prompt: Write 10 qualities that you appreciate in yourself (push yourself to get to 10) and 2 that you'd like to change or work on.
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 345

prompt: React to the following quote from Jim Butcher: 'When everything goes to hell, the people who stand by you without flinching - they are your family'
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 205
bonus_text: Having trouble getting started? List 3-5 difficult experiences in your life. List who was there to support you through those experiences and how they supported you.

prompt: List 20 things that make you happy
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 225
bonus_text: Make space in your life for the people, places, and activities that bring you joy. Consider if any activities on your list can be turned into healthful habits.

prompt: List the people you compare yourself to. In what ways do you compare yourself to them?
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 70-71.
bonus_text: Next to each person's name, write the emotion you typically feel when comparing yourself to them. How can you reframe how you view each person, from comparing to feeling empowered by observing the incredible people they are? Other people's successes have no negative impact on the person you are. Every person's life is unique and every person you admire has secret struggles and advantages you may never know about. Transform their achievements into your own inspiration and self-empowerment.

prompt: What is something you have a hard time being honest about, even to those you trust the most? Why?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 225

prompt: List the things you would say if you were speaking your truth. Under each truth, list what you assume might happen if you spoke those truths.
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 64-65.
bonus_text: On a scale of 1( not likely) and 10 (very likely), next to each assumption write the likelihood of your assumption coming true if you are truly open and honest. Know that when you take the risk of being open and honest with others, you gain power of influence. And no matter how they respond to your truth, by speaking openly and honestly, you are changing the world for good. Your risk, no matter the outcome, gains purpose.

prompt: Write about a time that your own strength surprised you
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 418

prompt: List the things you would tell your younger self to help them face the challenges or scary things in their life
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 110-111.
bonus_text:
Take five minutes today to close your eyes and visualize the younger you who still lives within you. All of our former selves still exist within us and deserve to receive the love, healing, and guidance that the grown-up you holds today. 
 In your five minute meditation, visualize the younger you that still exists and tell them all of the things you wrote down in your list. You are your own greatest healer, helper, and advocate.

prompt: How do you know when it is time to let something (or someone) go?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 302
bonus_text: Feeling stuck? Write about a time you have let something (or someone) go. How did you feel about it at the time? How do you feel about it now?

prompt: React to the following quote from The Alchemist by Paolo Coehlo: '“We can never judge the lives of others, because each person knows only their own pain and renunciation. It's one thing to feel that you are on the right path, but it's another to think that yours is the only path.'
List the labels people have given you and the ways they have tried to box you in.
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 102-103.
bonus_text:
We live in a society that tries to tell us who we are based off of an impossible template. We all get placed in boxes by others with words like 'good' or 'bad', 'selfish' or 'self-sacrificing', 'strong' or 'weak.' A truly brave person can live outside of these binaries; it just takes practice believing in your own truth rather than other's labels. 
 What is one affirming, positive, and powerful thing you know to be true about you.

prompt: What is something that you are insecure about? What is something that you are confident in?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 427

prompt: List the things about yourself that you think are silly, goofy, and funny
book: 52 Lists for Bravery by Moorea Seal; pg 100-101.
bonus_text: Which of these things do you think are embarrassing to share with others? This week's challenge is to move past the embarrassment and get silly! Sometimes it takes a little bravery to let your hair down and get goofy. Laughter is such a great healer and stress reliever, so go ahead- get funny!

prompt: What are some weird things you do when nobody else is around
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 364

prompt: React to the following quote from Invisible Monsters by Chuck Palahniuk: '“When you understand that what you're telling is just a story. It isn't happening anymore. When you realize the story you're telling is just words, when you can just crumble it up and throw your past in the trashcan, then we'll figure out who you're going to be.
If you could talk to someone that you have lost for just five more minutes, what would you say?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 449
bonus_text: Loss may refer to someone who has passed away or someone who abruptly/unexpectedly is no longer in your life.

prompt: List the feelings and thoughts that come up when you are avoiding something or procrastinating.
book: 52 Lists for Calm: Journaling Inspiration for Soothing Anxiety and Creating a Peaceful Life by Moorea Seal; pg 40-41
bonus_text:
Do you prefer to break up projects into smaller tasks that you can do day to day? Or do you prefer to have one big chunk of time to power through the whole thing? 
 Either way is okay! Some people are able to chip away at big projects whereas others are sprinters, which means they get their best work done, get the most inspiration, and feel the most satisfied when they work fast and hard. 
 The next time you feel anxiety rising from putting something off, instead remember how you work best, and assign yourself a day (or a series of days) and place to work on that thing.

prompt: What standards do you apply to yourself that you would never apply to others?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 458

prompt: Lise 5 activities you enjoy that you'd ideally like to spend more time doing
bonus_text: What is preventing you from doing those activities? How can you make more time for those activities in your life?

prompt: What are your main coping mechanisms right now? How are they serving you?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 473
bonus_text: Give it a try! List 3-5 coping mechanisms you would like to try. What steps are needed to implement these coping mechanisms?

prompt: List the ways you can love yourself more.
book: The 52 Lists Project: A Year of Weekly Journaling Inspiration by Moorea Seal; pg 108-109.
bonus_text: Start a weekly habit that is all about self-love that you will carry out until the end of the year (10 weeks). Try going for a hike, cooking a meal from scratch, or whatever speaks to you to symbolize your personal investment.

prompt: Write about a time you can remember being blindsided by something someone told you.
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 16
bonus_text: What were your emotions at the time? How did you react or cope with what you were told?

prompt: List all the things you would like to be able to do with more ease and lightness, and less worry, anxiety, or fear.
book: 52 Lists for Calm: Journaling Inspiration for Soothing Anxiety and Creating a Peaceful Life by Moorea Seal; pg 42-43.
bonus_text:
These are your goals as you move through the rest of this year. Choose one thing you want to focus on for the next two months and put an asterisk next to it. 
 It takes thirty days to break a habit, and thirty more days to establish a new healthy pattern. 
 What is one little thing you can practice doing to make that item on your list feel a little bit lighter, easier, and calmer?

prompt: What is a view about the world that has changed for you as you've gotten older?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 94

prompt: How do you tend to respond to crises? Write about your response to one you can remember. How do you feel about that?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 478

prompt: List the beliefs and values that influence your decision making.
book: 52 Lists for Calm: Journaling Inspiration for Soothing Anxiety and Creating a Peaceful Life by Moorea Seal; pg 52-53.
bonus_text:
Reflect on some of the big and little decisions you have made in the last week. Do those decisions align with the things you just listed about your personal values? Guess what - no one lives by the ideals they hold themselves to 100 percent of the time, and that is okay! 
 It does not make you a bad person; it makes you human, beautifully flawed and worthy of self-acceptance, compassion, and understanding. Your imperfection is what makes you human, not a robot, so perhaps you can ease up a little on how much you expect of yourself. You're doing a great job!

prompt: List the things you have been told not to do.
book: 52 Lists for Calm: Journaling Inspiration for Soothing Anxiety and Creating a Peaceful Life by Moorea Seal; pg 106-107
bonus_text:
Look at your list and ask yourself, 'Who is the true person stopping me from doing these things?' It's not the person who told you no; only you are the final decision maker in control of your actions and thoughts. 
 Review your list of your beliefs and values from last week. Are there things on the list you've been told not to do that align with your values - and that you actually might want to do? 
 Make a plan to do one thing on your list that feels safe and positive to you. Remember you get to live your life by your own standards.

prompt: Do you believe that life has a purpose? Why or why not?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 204

prompt: What are five things you would like to do before you die?
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 147
bonus_text: AFTER you have completed your list, think or write about the following: What is holding you back from doing these things? What steps could you take to realistically make these things happen?

prompt: React to the following quote from The Perks of Being a Wallflower by Stephen Chbosky: 'We accept the love we think we deserve.
book: 500 Journal Prompts For Mental Health, Creativity, and Personal Exploration by Robert Duff, PH.D.; prompt 464
bonus_text: What emotions does this bring up for you. Does this make you think of a specific person and/or situation?

prompt: List the most memorable moments of your year.
book: The 52 Lists Project: A Year of Weekly Journaling Inspiration by Moorea Seal; pg 142-143.
bonus_text: What a year it has been! Like any year, there were ups and downs, highs and lows. But because you took the time to write out your thoughts and feelings each week through this journal, you now have incredible documentation of all the ways you have processed and grown. Take some time this week to read through your past pages and revel in the personal growth and joy you have experienced. You did it!

prompt: What memories, wisdom, and goals would you like to carry into the upcoming year and what would you like to leave behind.
